description:
Morocco's Ministry of Education issues, on August 28th, a 60-page notice that includes a Health Protocol that school staff and students are expected to adhere to upon the reopening of schools. The Protocol is divided into five parts and includes key measures such as: 
1) Students' temperature must be measured each morning before leaving for school. If a student has a high temperature or has COVID-19 symptoms they ought to stay at home. If a COVID-19 infection is suspected the school as well as health authorities must be notified. 
2) Schools must appoint a member of staff to be responsible for implementing the Health Protocol and must hold a preparatory meeting at least one week prior to the start of the new school year to co-ordinate tasks related to the Health Protocol. 
3) Staff who are immunocompromised or who live with people with higher risk of severe symptoms from COVID-19 can, the Ministry suggests, work remotely. 
4) Agile communication between schools and students regarding any changes is encouraged. 
5)Social distancing and regular disinfecting must be in place on the school grounds, and in school buses all students must wear masks irrespective of age.

description:
On March 22nd 2020, Morocco's Government Council adopts a Draft Decree Law No. 2.20.292 that promulgates provisions relating to the "state of health emergency" as well as procedures for its declaration. The legal framework allows for a "state of health emergency" to be declared in any region, prefecture, province or commune, or throughout the whole national territory of Morocco if necessary, whenever the safety of people is threatened by an epidemic or contagious disease and urgent measures are needed protect them from the disease and curb its spread. Under a state of health emergency the following is authorised: 
1) Public authorities may take any necessary measures by means of decrees, administrative decisions, circulars or statements to counter the deterioration of the epidemiological situation and to save lives and ensure people's security. 
2) Violations of decisions made by public authorities during are punishable by 1-3 months of imprisonment and/or a fine of 300-1,200 dirhams. 
3) Exceptional emergency measures of an economic, financial, social or environmental nature that can contribute directly to dealing with the negative impacts of the "state of health emergency" can be taken by the government.

description:
Morocco's Ministry of Education issues, on August 28th, a 60-page notice that includes a Health Protocol that school staff and students are expected to adhere to upon the reopening of schools. The Protocol is divided into five parts and includes key measures such as: 
1) Students' temperature must be measured each morning before leaving for school. If a student has a high temperature or has COVID-19 symptoms they ought to stay at home. If a COVID-19 infection is suspected the school as well as health authorities must be notified. 
2) Schools must appoint a member of staff to be responsible for implementing the Health Protocol and must hold a preparatory meeting at least one week prior to the start of the new school year to co-ordinate tasks related to the Health Protocol. 
3) Staff who are immunocompromised or who live with people with higher risk of severe symptoms from COVID-19 can, the Ministry suggests, work remotely. 
4) Agile communication between schools and students regarding any changes is encouraged. 
5)Social distancing and regular disinfecting must be in place on the school grounds, and in school buses all students must wear masks irrespective of age.
